statement.tex: %text What would be the largest term numerically in the expansion of $(2+3x)^9$ if $x=\dfrac{3}{2}$? %
\\ \textbf{Condition for largest term.}\\ %text If $T_n$ be the largest term in the expansion, then \underline\text{would the following be true}? %
\\ %text \textbf{Right or wrong?} $T_n$ will keep increasing as long as $\ldots$ \textbf{Note: }$x=\frac{3}{2}$. %
\\ %text Which means, the \underline\text{largest term} will be the following. \textbf{Right or wrong?} %

reason.tex:
\begin{align} (2+3x)^9 &= \overbrace{T_1 + T_2 + \cdots + T_{10}}^ {\longrightarrow\text{ increasing powers of x}} \\ &= \overbrace{T_{10} + T_9 + \cdots + T_1}^ {\longrightarrow\text{ decreasing powers of x}} \end{align} \\ %text Either is fine. But pick one and stick with it. We will use $T_1 + T_2 + \cdots +T_{10}$.
And hence, % \begin{align} (2+3x)^9 &= 2^9\cdot \left(1+\frac{3}{2}x\right)^9 \\ &= 2^9\cdot \sum_{n=1}^{10}\, ^9C_{n-1}\left(\frac{3}{2}x\right)^{n-1}\cdot 1^{9-(n-1)} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^{10}\, 2^9\cdot ^9C_{n-1}\left(\frac{3}{2}x\right)^{n-1} = \sum_{n=1}^{10}T_n \\ \implies T_n &= 2^9\cdot ^9C_{n-1}\left(\frac{3}{2}x\right)^{n-1} \end{align}
